individual.title.title.segment: U.S. BANK NATIONAL ASSOCIATION, et al. AS TRUSTEE FOR LEHMAN BROTHER STRUCTURED ASSET SECURITIES CORPORATION SASCO 2007-BNCI, and DOES 1 through 50, inclusive

content.attorney.attorney.line: Marva Dillard, Courtroom Deputy, ATTORNEYS PRESENT FOR PLAINTIFFS: None
None Present, Court Reporter, ATTORNEYS PRESENT FOR DEFENDANTS: None

head.headtext: PROCEEDINGS: MINUTE ORDER GRANTING MOTION TO DISMISS AND REMANDING ACTION TO RIVERSIDE COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT (IN CHAMBERS)

content.judge.judge.line: HONORABLE VIRGINIA A. PHILLIPS, U.S. DISTRICT JUDGE

para.paratext: The Court has received and considered the papers filed in support of, and in opposition to, Defendant's “Motion to Dismiss the Complaint” (“Motion”). The matter is appropriate for resolution without hearing pursuant to Local Rule 7-15; the Court VACATES the hearing currently set on August 10, 2009 at 10:00 a.m. For the following reasons, the Court GRANTS the Motion and remands the action to the California Superior Court for Riverside County.

On May 22, 2009, Plaintiffs Terry Robinson-Hines and Tony Hines (“Plaintiffs”) filed a Complaint in the California Superior Court for the County of Riverside against Defendant U.S. Bank National Association, as trustee for Lehman Brothers Structured Asset Securities Corporation SASCO 2007-BNC1, with the following claims: (1) declaratory relief; (2) wrongful foreclosure; (3) “to cancel trustee's deed upon sale”; (4) “to vacate and set aside foreclosure sale”; (5) quiet title; (6) breach of contract; (7) fraud; (8) negligent misrepresentation; (9) violation of the Truth in Lending Act (“TILA”); and (10) injunction. (See Not. of Removal at ¶ 1; Compl.) On June 19, 2009, Defendant removed the action to this Court on the basis of federal question jurisdiction, 28 U.S.C. § 1331.
On July 2, 2009, Defendant filed a “Motion to Dismiss the Complaint” (“Motion”) and a “Request for Judicial Notice” (“RJN”). Plaintiffs, appearing pro se, filed timely Opposition on July 27, 2009.

Under Rule 12(b)(6), a party may bring a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted. As a general matter, the Federal Rules require only that a plaintiff provide “‘a short and plain statement of the claim’ that will give the defendant fair notice of what the plaintiff's claim is and the grounds upon which it rests.” Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41, 47 (1957) (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a)(2)); Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 555 (2007). In addition, the Court must accept all material allegations in the complaint — as well as any reasonable inferences to be drawn from them — as true. See Doe v. United States, 419 F.3d at 1062; ARC Ecology v. U.S. Dep't of Air Force, 411 F.3d at 1096.

“While a complaint attacked by a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss does not need detailed factual allegations, a plaintiff's obligation to provide the ‘grounds’ of his ‘entitlement to relief’ requires more than labels and conclusions, and a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action will not do.” Bell Atlantic, 550 U.S. at 555 (citations omitted). Rather, the allegations in the complaint “must be enough to raise a right to relief above the speculative level.” Id.

In other words, the allegations must be plausible on the face of the complaint. See Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. __, 129 S. Ct. 1937, 1949 (2009). “The plausibility standard is not akin to a ‘probability requirement,’ but it asks for more than a sheer possibility that a defendant has acted unlawfully. Where a complaint pleads facts that are ‘merely consistent with’ a defendant's liability, it stops short of the line between possibility and plausibility of ‘entitlement to relief.’” Id. (citations and internal quotations omitted).

Although the scope of review is limited to the contents of the complaint, the Court may also consider exhibits submitted with the complaint, Hal Roach Studios, Inc. v. Richard Feiner & Co., 896 F.2d 1542, 1555 n.19 (9th Cir. 1990), and “take judicial notice of matters of public record outside the pleadings,” Mir v. Little Co. of Mary Hosp., 844 F.2d 646, 649 (9th Cir. 1988).

Defendant moves the Court to dismiss each of Plaintiffs' claims. (See Mot. at 1.) The Court evaluates Plaintiffs' TILA claim first, to determine whether or not Plaintiffs have stated a claim for violation of a federal law to satisfy the Court's federal question subject matter jurisdiction requirements.

Plaintiffs' TILA claim is based on the following factual allegation: “the amount of annual percentage rate was incorrectly calculated” by Defendant in Plaintiffs' closed-end credit transaction. (Compl. at ¶¶ 50-52.) For this alleged TILA violation, Plaintiffs seek “damages in an amount to be proven at the time of trial” and pray “for a cancellation and rescission of the BNC Deed of Trust for violation of the Truth in Lending Act.” (Compl. at ¶ 52, Prayer for Relief at ¶ 10.) The Court construes Plaintiffs' Complaint as seeking damages and rescission under their TILA claim.

Defendant argues Plaintiffs' TILA claim seeking damages is time-barred by the one-year statute of limitations imposed on such claims. (See Mot. at 18 (citing 15 U.S.C. § 1640(e).) Plaintiffs allege they executed the loan documents on or about June 20, 2007; Plaintiffs filed their Complaint on May 22, 2009. (See Compl. at ¶ 7; Not. of Removal at ¶ 1.) Accordingly, in so far as Plaintiffs seek damages for a TILA violation, their claim is barred. See 15 U.S.C. § 1640(e).

To the extent Plaintiffs seek rescission, TILA's rescission remedy does not apply because Plaintiffs' claim concerns “a residential mortgage transaction.” See 15 U.S.C. § 1635(e)(1) (listing a residential mortgage transaction as an exemption from the three-year TILA rescission remedy).

Plaintiffs have no remedy under TILA, as neither damages nor rescission are available to them; thus, Plaintiffs are unable to state a claim for violation of TILA. As their TILA claim provided the only basis for federal subject matter jurisdiction in this case, the Court does not reach Plaintiffs' remaining claims.
For the foregoing reasons, the Court GRANTS the Motion to Dismiss and REMANDS the action to the California Superior Court for Riverside County.
